column1: Nakhon Nayok (Thai: นครนายก
column2: pronounced [ná(ʔ).kʰɔ̄ːn nāː.jók]) is one of the central provinces (changwat) of Thailand
column3: established by the Act Establishing Changwat Samut Prakan
column8: which came into force on 9 May 1946.

column1: Neighboring provinces are (from north clockwise) Saraburi
Nakhon Nayok is known for waterfalls and fruit varieties.
Nakon Nayok is a nearby province to Bangkok and has various tourist attractions. Khao Yai National Park
column2: Thailands oldest national park is in partly in Nakhon Nayok povince and attracts many tourists . Khun Dan Prakarn Chon Dam is another tourist attraction 2 hours outside of Bangkok in Nakhon Nayok .

column1: The word nakhon originates from the Sanskrit word nagara (Devanagari:  नगर) meaning 'city'
column2: and the word nayok is thought to have been derived from the Sanskrit nāyaka (Devanagari:  नायक) meaning 'leader' or 'captain'. However
column4: na means '[tax of] rice field' and yok means 'exempted'. Hence the name of the province literally means 'tax-free city'.

column1: The city of Nakhon Nayok dates back to the Dvaravati Kingdom
column2: probably founded in the 11th century. Ruins from this time are visible at Mueang Boran Dong Lakhon south of the modern city. Originally named Mueang Lablae
column3: the name "Nakhon Nayok" was assigned to it in 1350
column4: when it became a garrison town of the Ayutthaya kingdom protecting the eastern boundary.

column1: On 1 January 1943 the government downgraded Nakhon Nayok Province and combined it with Prachinburi Province
column2: except for Ban Na District which became part of Saraburi Province. On 9 May 1946 the province was re-established.

column1: The provincial seal shows an elephant holding an ear of rice with its trunk. This symbolizes fertile rice fields
column2: as well as the forests with numerous elephants. In the background two piles of straw
column4: and clouds symbolizing the natural beauty of the province.

column1: The provincial flower and tree is the silk cotton tree (Cochlospermum religiosum).
Nakhon Nayok province has a tropical savanna climate (Köppen climate classification category Aw). Winters are dry and warm. Temperatures rise until May. Mansoon season runs from May through October
column2: with heavy rain and somewhat cooler temperatures during the day
column3: although nights remain warm. Climate statistics: maximum temperature is 42.2 °C (108 °F) in April and lowest temperature is 12.2 °C (54 °F) in December. Highest average temperature is 36.8 °C (98.2 °F) in April and minimum average temperature is 20.5 °C (68.9 °F) in December. Average annual rainfall is 1
column4: 823 millimeters in 134 days. Maximum daily rainfall is 195 millimeters in August.

column1: The northern part of the province is in the Sankamphaeng Range
column2: the southern prolongation of the Dong Phaya Yen mountains
column4: 292 meter high Yod Khao Kiew. Most of that area is covered by the Khao Yai National Park. The central part of the province however is a rather flat river plain formed by the Nakhon Nayok River. The southern part of the province has relatively infertile acidic soil.

column1: The main river of the province is the Nakhon Nayok River. It joins the Prachinburi River at Pak Nam Yothaka in Ban Sang District
column3: which then becomes the Bang Pa Kong River.

column1: The province is divided into four districts (amphoes). The districts are further divided into 41 subdistricts (tambons) and 403 villages (mubans).

As of 26 November 2019 there are: one Nakhon Nayok Provincial Administration Organisation (ongkan borihan suan changwat) and 6 municipal (thesaban) areas in the province. Nakhon Nayok has town (thesaban mueang) status. Further 5 subdistrict municipalities (thesaban tambon). The non-municipal areas are administered by 39 Subdistrict Administrative Organisations - SAO (ongkan borihan suan tambon).

column2: United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Thailand has tracked progress on human development at sub-national level using the Human achievement index (HAI)
column3: a composite index covering all the eight key areas of human development. National Economic and Social Development Board (NESDB) has taken over this task since 2017.
